body_html:
You're renaming the Python object entcoeff from a tf.Variable to the return value of tf.Print before trying tf.assign, which is why it crashes (Tensors are immutable).

I think @facaiy wanted something like this which should work:

x = tf.Variable([0], dtype=tf.float32, trainable=False)
entcoeff = tf.Print(x, [x, "printing"])
tf.assign(x, [-1.])

Going by the documentation of tf.Print it seems like your example should work though. A little weird that it turns Variable into Tensor considering:

Returns:
Same tensor as input_.

IMO a bug or unclear documentation.

I think @facaiy wanted something like this which should work:

Same tensor as input_.

IMO a bug or unclear documentation.
body:
You're renaming the Python object `entcoeff` from a `tf.Variable` to the return value of `tf.Print` before trying `tf.assign`, which is why it crashes (Tensors are immutable).

I think @facaiy wanted something like this which should work:
```python
x = tf.Variable([0], dtype=tf.float32, trainable=False)
entcoeff = tf.Print(x, [x, "printing"])
tf.assign(x, [-1.])
```

Going by the [documentation of tf.Print](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Print) it seems like your example should work though. A little weird that it turns `Variable` into `Tensor` considering:
>Returns: 
>Same tensor as input_.

IMO a bug or unclear documentation.
